item.title: By: evanstonjew
item.dc:creator: evanstonjew
item.description:
I was at BJ one time for a Friday night service. What I saw was indeed very impressive, but not exactly as conceptualized in the article. The first thing I noticed was the theater in the round quality and the use of a string quartet. If every shteibel in America had the acoustics of that room and a similar group of talented musicians they could achieve similar effects with much less than a minyan of 500 people. This is a let out all the stops performance. If normal yekkish -litvish davening is like a German lied this is Andrew Lloyd Weber's Evita or maybe even Bob Fosse's Cabaret.
A second thing that struck me was the change from the urgency and emotional punch of Rabbi Meyer's activities during the junta and the Save Darfur banner that was strung across the width of the synagogue. I am not convinced Carlebach and left liberal politics are natural partners. This crowd didn't accomplish much in Darfur and I doubt if they will be much more successful in saving the planet.
I also question whether the Art Green model of kabbalah describes what's going on. The davening is hugely enjoyable, I agree. If this was my regular shul, I would imagine after davening I would be in the mood for a good meal with family and friends or maybe a long walk with a lot of banter and schmoozing. Transcendence I would leave for some other time. I don't think my reaction is atypical.
Having made all these picky-picky comments I believe Conservative and Reform congregations have a lot to learn from BJ for all the obvious reasons.
